case_name: Saraspur Mills v. Ramanlal Chimanlal and others

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 1957 of 1968 is an appeal by special leave

anchor.surface_text: Civil Appeal No. 1957 of 1968. Appeal by special leave from the Award dated March. 26, 1968 of the Industrial Court Gujarat Ahmedabad in Appeal  IC  No. 58 of 1966.

facts.text: Appeal is from the Award dated March 26, 1968 of the Industrial Court Gujarat Ahmedabad in Appeal IC No. 58 of 1966

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the Award dated March. 26, 1968 of the Industrial Court Gujarat Ahmedabad in Appeal  IC  No. 58 of 1966. V. Gupte, P. C. Bhartari, and J. B, Dadachanji Co., for the appellant.

facts.text: Industrial Court Gujarat reversed an order made by the 2nd Labour Court, Ahmedabad

anchor.surface_text: GROVER, J This is an Appeal by special leave from an Order of the industrial Court,, Gujarat which reversed an order made by the 2nd Labour Court, Ahmedabad.

facts.text: Ramanlal Chimanlal and others are the workers of a canteen run by the Saraspur Mills Canteen Co-operative Society Limited, Ahmedabad

anchor.surface_text: Ramanlal Chimanlal and others are the workers of a canteen which is run by the Saraspur Mills Canteen Co-operative Society Limited, Ahmedabad  hereinafter called the company operative society .

facts.text: The appellant company is responsible for maintaining the canteen under the provisions of S. 46 of the Factories Act and the rules made thereunder

anchor.surface_text: The appellant companypany is responsible for maintaining the canteen under the provisions of S. 46 of the Factories Act and the rules made thereunder.

facts.text: The appellant handed over to the co-operative society the task of running the canteen

anchor.surface_text: The appellant handed over to the companyoperative society the task of running the canteen.

facts.text: Workers filed an application before the 2nd Labour Court at Ahmedabad under S. 79 of the Bombay Industrial Relations Act, 1946

anchor.surface_text: The workers mentioned above filed an application before the 2nd Labour Court at Ahmedabad under S. 79 of the Bombay Industrial Relations Act, 1946  hereinafter called the Act , companyplaining that the appellant was number paying them the wages

facts.text: Workers complained that the appellant was not paying them wages and dearness allowances as per the Award of the Bombay Industrial Court in Reference No. 18 of 1947 and supplementary Awards of 1956 and 1962

anchor.surface_text: companyplaining that the appellant was number paying them the wages and dearness allowances as per the directions companytained in the Award of the Bombay Industrial Court made in Reference No. 18 of 1947 and supplementary Award given in certain miscellaneous applications. of 1956 and 1962 respectively relating to additional wages sanctioned by the said Award.

facts.text: Workers alleged that by virtue of amendments in the Act in the definition of employer they became workers of the appellant bound to pay as per Awards

anchor.surface_text: It was alleged by the applicants in support of their claim that by virtue of certain amendments made in the Act in the definition of the word employer they became workers of the appellant, which was bound to pay wages and dearness allowances settled by the aforesaid Award and the supplementary Awards referred to.

facts.text: Appellant denied that the workers were its employees

anchor.surface_text: The appellant denied the allegations of the workmen that they were its employees.

facts.text: Appellant claimed workers had never been employed by the appellant or its agent or contractor but by licensees of the appellant

anchor.surface_text: It was claimed that the aforesaid workers had never been employed either by the appellant or by its agent or companytractor. The workers in fact were stated to have beep employed by the licences of the appellant and, therefore, there was numberquestion of the wage settlements or Awards being binding on, the appellant.

facts.text: 2nd Labour Court dismissed the claim of the workmen by its Order dated 14th April, 1966

anchor.surface_text: The 2nd Labour Court by its Order dated 14th April, 1966 dismissed the claim of the workmen, who filed an appeal before the Industrial Court, which was allowed by its order dated 26th March, 1968.

facts.text: Industrial Court allowed the appeal by order dated 26th March, 1968

anchor.surface_text: The 2nd Labour Court by its Order dated 14th April, 1966 dismissed the claim of the workmen, who filed an appeal before the Industrial Court, which was allowed by its order dated 26th March, 1968.

facts.text: Industrial Court held that employees of the co-operative society working in the canteen were employees of the appellant and payable wages per Awards

anchor.surface_text: The Industrial Court held that the employees of the companyoperative society, who were working in the canteen were employees of the appellant and, their wages and dearness allowance etc. were payable in accordance with the Awards mentioned before.

facts.text: Industrial Court directed appellant to pay difference in wages and dearness allowance per Awards

anchor.surface_text: The direction was made that the appellant should pay the difference in wages and dearness allowance in accordance with those Awards.

facts.text: Gujarat Legislature passed an Act in 1962 amending clauses 13 and 14 of Section 3 of the Act

anchor.surface_text: The Gujarat Legislature passed an Act in 1962 amending clause,  13  and  14  of Section 3 of the Act.

facts.text: Bombay High Court had held that employees employed by the co-operative society could not be treated as employees under the Act

anchor.surface_text: The Bombay High Court had held in certain matters which were brought before it that in spite of the fact that the L797Sup Cl/73 companyoperative society was mentioned in the Bombay Factories Rules, 1950, the employee employed by the companyoperative society companyld number be treated as employees under the Act.

facts.text: Factories Act, 1948 came into force on April 1, 1949

anchor.surface_text: The Factories Act, 1948 came into force on April 1, 1949.

facts.text: Supreme Court dismissed the appeal with costs

anchor.surface_text: The appeal, therefore, must fail and it is dismissed with companyts.

facts.text: Appellant under statutory obligation under section 46 of Factories Act to maintain canteen

anchor.surface_text: It is companytended that the appellant was under a statutory obligation because of section 46 of the Factories Act and the relevant rules made thereunder to maintain the Canteen for the workers

anchor.surface_text: The Gujarat Legislature passed an Act in 1962 amending clause,  13  and  14  of Section 3 of the Act. After the amendment these clauses run as follows  13  employee means any person  including an apprentice  employed in any industry to any skilled or unskilled manual, supervisory, technical or clerical work for hire or reward, whether the terms of employment be express or implied and includes  a  a person employed in the execution of any work in respect of which the owner of an undertaking is an employer within the meaning of sub-clause  e  of clause  14 .

concepts.interpretation: Extended meaning including persons employed in entrusted work; statutory employees created by fiction

interpretation_anchor.surface_text: ociety was mentioned in the Bombay Factories Rules, 1950, the employee employed by the companyoperative society companyld number be treated as employe

anchor.surface_text: 14  employer includes- Where the owner of any undertaking in the companyrse of or for the purpose of companyducting the undertaking entrusts the execution of the whole or any part of any work which is ordinarily a part of the undertaking to any person otherwise than as the servant or agent of the owner, the owner of the undertaking The Industrial. Court was of the view that the term employee under the Act had been given an extended meaning.

concepts.interpretation: Owner is employer if entrusts ordinarily part of undertaking work to non-servant/agent; fulfills 4 conditions: entrustment in course of undertaking, otherwise than servant/agent, ordinarily part of undertaking

anchor.surface_text: Prior to the Act, Bombay Industrial Disputes Act 1938 was in force in the erstwhile province of Bombay. Under that Act numberstatutory employees were created but only those person-, who were directly employed by the employer were treated as employees.

concepts.interpretation: No statutory employees, only direct employees
concepts.unlisted_description: Repealed predecessor Act without extended employee definition

anchor.surface_text: The Gujarat Legislature passed an Act in 1962 amending clause,  13  and  14  of Section 3 of the Act.

concepts.unlisted_description: Amends BIR Act definitions of employee and employer

anchor.surface_text: The Industrial. Court was of the view that the term employee under the Act had been given an extended meaning. An employee Was number only a person who was employed by the employer or over whom the employer had companytrol, but also certain types of persons had been companystituted statutory employees under the Act.

issues.text: The only question which requires determination is whether the canteen workers employed by the co-operative society could be treated as employees of the appellant within the meaning of the relevant provisions of the Act for the purpose of payment of their wages in spite of the fact that they are employees of the co-operative society and were being paid wages by that society.

anchor.surface_text: The only question which requires determination is whether the canteen workers employed by the co-operative society could be treated as employees of the appellant within the meaning of the relevant provisions of the Act for the purpose of payment of their wages in spite of the fact that they are employees of the co-operative society and were being paid wages by that society.

issues.text: on a proper construction of the amended clauses 13 and 14 of Section 3 of the Act, the workers, employed in the canteen which was being run by the co-operative society, could not have been held to be employees of the appellant.

anchor.surface_text: The sole point which has been strenuously urged on behalf of the appellant is that on a proper construction of the amended clauses  13  and  14  of Section 3 of the Act, the workers, employed in the canteen which was being run by the co-operative society, could not have been held to be employees of the appellant.

arguments.claim: By virtue of certain amendments made in the Act in the definition of the word employer they became workers of the appellant, which was bound to pay wages and dearness allowances settled by the aforesaid Award and the supplementary Awards

anchor.surface_text: It was alleged by the applicants in support of their claim that by virtue of certain amendments made in the Act in the definition of the word employer they became workers of the appellant, which was bound to pay wages and dearness allowances settled by the aforesaid Award and the supplementary Awards referred to.

arguments.court_reasoning: Extended definition under amended S.3(13) and (14) creates statutory fiction making them employees

arguments.claim: The appellant was running the canteen only because it was under an obligation to do so under the Factories Act and the rules made thereunder. Thus the running of the canteen was an ordinary part of the undertaking of the appellant

anchor.surface_text: The case of the workmen was that the appellant was running the canteen only because it was under an obligation to do so under the Factories Act and the rules made thereunder. Thus the running of the canteen was an ordinary part of the undertaking of the appellant. It was admitted that the appellant did not run the canteen itself but handed over the premises to the co-operative society to run the canteen for the use and welfare of the mills employees and discharge its legal obligations.

arguments.claim: Before such a person could become the employee of the owner of the undertaking, the conditions that must be fulfilled were: 1. the owner must entrust work; 2. in course of conducting undertaking; 3. otherwise than servant/agent; 4. ordinarily part of undertaking

anchor.surface_text: Before such a person could become the employee of the owner of the undertaking, the conditions that must be fulfilled were 1 the owner of the undertaking must entrust to any person the execution of the whole or any part of any work 2 such entrustment must be in the course of or for the purpose of conducting the under- taking 3 such entrustment must be otherwise than as the servant or agent of the owner and 4 such work must be any work which is ordinarily a part of the undertaking.

arguments.court_reasoning: All four conditions satisfied in this case

arguments.claim: The matter seems to be concluded by the judgment of this Court in Civil Appeal No. 1044 of 1968... identical argument... gardeners... could not be said to fall within the definition

anchor.surface_text: The matter seems to be concluded by the judgment of this Court in Civil Appeal No. 1044 of 1968 decided on April 14, 1972, in which an identical argument had been addressed that certain gardeners who had been employed by a contractor for working in the gardens of the textile mills, could not be said to fall within the definition of the word employed as contained in Section 3 13 of the Act.

arguments.claim: Reference to Basti Sugar Mills Ltd. v. Ram Ujagar... workmen fell within definition... employed by contractor... work ordinarily part of industry

anchor.surface_text: In that case reference was made to the decision in Basti Sugar Mills Ltd. Ram Ujagar and Ors. It had been held that the workmen fell within the definition of that word as given by S. 2 z of the U.P. Industrial Disputes Act 1947 as they were persons employed in the industry to do manual work for reward.

arguments.claim: Ahmedabad Mfg. Calico Printing Co. Ltd. v. Their Workmen... relied on Basti Sugar... workers need not be directly connected with manufacture

anchor.surface_text: The High Court in Ahmedabad Mfg. Calico Printing Co. Ltd. Ors v. Their Workmen had relied on the above ratio and came to the conclusion that the workers in order to come within the definition of an employee need not necessarily be directly connected with the manufacture of textile fabrics.

arguments.claim: Under the Factories Act it was the duty of the appellant to run and maintain the canteen... ratio of Ahmedabad Manufacturing... fully applicable

holdings.text: The matter is concluded by the judgment of this Court in Civil Appeal No. 1044 of 1968 where an identical argument that workers employed by a contractor could not fall within the definition of employee under Section 3(13) of the Act was rejected.

anchor.surface_text: The matter seems to be concluded by the judgment of this Court in Civil Appeal No. 1044 of 1968 decided on April 14, 1972, in which an identical argument had been addressed that certain gardeners who had been employed by a contractor for working in the gardens of the textile mills, could not be said to fall within the definition of the word employed as contained in Section 3 13 of the Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Identical argument addressed and rejected in prior Supreme Court judgment involving gardeners employed by contractor.

holdings.text: The ratio of the decision in Ahmedabad Mfg. Calico Printing Co. Ltd. v. Their Workmen is fully applicable as under the Factories Act it was the duty of the appellant to run and maintain the canteen.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Statutory duty under Factories Act to maintain canteen equates to ordinarily part of undertaking, analogous to prior case on amenities.

holdings.text: The appeal must fail and is dismissed with costs.

anchor.surface_text: The appeal, therefore, must fail and it is dismissed with costs.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Workers held to be employees of appellant under amended BIR Act based on precedents and statutory interpretation.

anchor.surface_text: Civil Appeal No. 1044 of 1968 decided on April 14, 1972, in which an identical argument had been addressed that certain gardeners who had been employed by a contractor for working in the gardens of the textile mills, could not be said to fall within the definition of the word "employed" as contained in Section 3 (13) of the Act.

precedents.cited_proposition: employees of a contractor engaged in work ordinarily part of the undertaking (gardens for textile mills) fall within the definition of 'employed' under Section 3(13) of the Bombay Industrial Relations Act
precedents.cited_holding: gardeners employed by contractor are employees under the Act

precedents.citation: Basti Sugar Mills Ltd. Ram Ujagar and Ors. 1964 2 S.C.R. 838

anchor.surface_text: Basti Sugar Mills Ltd. Ram Ujagar and Ors.  1  It had been held that the workmen fell within the definition of that word as given by S. 2 (z) of the U.P. Industrial Disputes Act 1947 as they were persons employed in the industry to do manual work for reward. The workmen had been employed by a contractor with whom the mills had contracted in the course of conducting the industry for execution by the said contractor of the work of removal of press mud which is ordinarily a part of the industry.

precedents.case_name: Basti Sugar Mills Ltd. v. Ram Ujagar and Ors.
precedents.cited_proposition: an employee engaged in a work or operation which was incidentally connected with the main industry was a workman if other requirements of the statute were satisfied
precedents.cited_holding: workmen employed by contractor for removal of press mud are workmen under U.P. Industrial Disputes Act

precedents.citation: Ahmedabad Mfg. Calico Printing Co. Ltd. Ors v. Their Workmen 1953 II L.L.J. 647

anchor.surface_text: The High Court in Ahmedabad Mfg. Calico Printing Co. Ltd. Ors v. Their Workmen  2  had relied on the above ratio and came to the conclusion that the workers in order to come within the definition of an employee need not necessarily be directly connected with the manufacture of textile fabrics. The decision in Basti Sugar Mills case was treated as binding in the former case.

precedents.case_name: Ahmedabad Manufacturing & Calico Printing Co. Ltd. v. Their Workmen
precedents.cited_proposition: workers need not necessarily be directly connected with the manufacture of textile fabrics to come within the definition of employee
precedents.cited_holding: Malis working in gardens and bungalows are workers as engaged in operations incidentally connected with the main industry
